speaker: Doctor
text: What's been going on with your gait and limb ataxia? When did you first start noticing these symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been a few weeks now, but I've been having trouble walking straight. I feel like I'm stumbling around and losing my balance. It's like I'm drunk, but I haven't been drinking."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any other symptoms besides the gait and limb ataxia, such as numbness, tingling, or weakness in your limbs?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been feeling really weak in my right arm, like I can't lift it as easily as I used to. And sometimes, my fingers feel like they're tingling or numb. It's hard to describe, but it's like my arm is just not working right."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your medical history? Have you had any previous conditions or illnesses that might be related to your current symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've had some issues with my digestive system in the past. I was diagnosed with a condition a few years ago and have been taking medication for it. But I've never had any problems like this before."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the condition you were diagnosed with and the medication you're taking for it?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's something I've been dealing with for a while now. I've been on medication for it, but it's not really been helping like it used to. I've been having some issues with it getting worse over time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the medication you're taking for your condition and have you noticed any changes in your bowel habits recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been taking a medication for a while now, but it's not really been working as well as it used to. I've been having some issues with my bowel movements, they've been a bit more... unpredictable lately."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your bowel movements that might be related to your gait and limb ataxia? For example, have you had any episodes of diarrhea or constipation that might be contributing to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, my bowel movements have been all over the place lately. Sometimes I'll have a normal day, and then other times I'll have to run to the bathroom multiple times. It's like my body is just not listening to me anymore. And it's not just the frequency, it's the consistency too. Sometimes it's like I'm trying to hold it in, and other times it's like it's just going to come out no matter what."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any weight loss or changes in your appetite recently?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, I have been losing weight lately. I've been eating the same amount of food, but I just can't seem to gain any weight back. And my appetite has been off too. Sometimes I'll be starving and other times I'll just have no interest in eating at all."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the weight loss you've experienced? Is it gradual or sudden?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been gradual, I think. I've been noticing it for a few months now. At first, it was just a little bit, but lately, it's been more noticeable. I've been trying to eat more, but nothing seems to be helping."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your family medical history? Have you had any relatives with neurological disorders or conditions that might be related to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't really know if I have any relatives with neurological disorders. My mom has some issues with her joints, but I don't know if that's related to anything like this. My dad passed away when I was young, so I didn't really get to know him well enough to ask about his health."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any changes in your vision, such as double vision, blurred vision, or sensitivity to light?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, yes. Sometimes when I'm walking, I feel like I'm seeing double. It's like my eyes are crossing or something. And sometimes, everything looks a little blurry. It's hard to describe, but it's like my vision is just off."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first started noticing the double vision and blurred vision? Was it around the same time as the gait and limb ataxia started?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think the double vision and blurred vision started a little bit before the gait and limb ataxia. I remember having trouble reading a book one day, and everything looked blurry. And then, a few days later, I started feeling like I was stumbling around. It's hard to pinpoint exactly when it started, but I think it was a gradual thing."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your digestive condition and the medication you're taking for it? Have you noticed any changes in your stool consistency or frequency since starting the medication?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been a bit of a challenge, to be honest. My stool consistency has been all over the place. Sometimes it's loose and watery, and other times it's hard and dry. And the frequency... well, like I said, it's been unpredictable. Some days I'll have a normal bowel movement, and others I'll have to run to the bathroom multiple times. It's like my body is just not listening to me anymore."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your job and daily activities? Have you noticed any changes in your ability to perform tasks or do things you normally do?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been having trouble with some of my daily activities, yeah. Simple things like walking to the kitchen or getting dressed in the morning have become a challenge. And at work, I've been struggling to keep up with my usual tasks. It's like my body is just not cooperating with my brain anymore."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any recent infections or illnesses that might be contributing to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been feeling a bit run down lately, but I don't think it's anything serious. I've been getting a lot of colds and flu going around where I work, so I'm just trying to take it easy and hope it passes. But to be honest, I'm a bit worried about what's going on with my body. It feels like everything is just off, you know?"

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any changes in your speech or language skills, such as slurred words or difficulty finding the right words?

speaker: Patient
text: "Hmm, I'm not really sure. I mean, I've been having trouble finding the right words sometimes, but I just thought it was because I was tired or stressed. But now that you mention it, I do feel like I'm having a harder time articulating my thoughts. It's like my brain is trying to get the words out, but they're not coming out quite right."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the difficulty you're experiencing with finding the right words? Is it a gradual thing, or has it been sudden?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's been a gradual thing, I think. I've noticed it getting worse over the past few weeks. Sometimes I'll be talking to someone and I'll know exactly what I want to say, but the words just won't come out right. It's like my brain is trying to catch up with my mouth, but it's not happening. And sometimes, I'll be trying to think of the right word and it's just not there. It's really frustrating."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation you're experiencing in your right arm? Is it a numbness, tingling, or weakness?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's a bit of all three, to be honest. Sometimes my arm feels numb, like it's not even there. Other times, it's like I'm feeling pins and needles, like it's tingling. And then there are times when it just feels weak, like I can't lift it or move it like I want to. It's hard to describe, but it's like my arm is just not cooperating with the rest of my body."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when the numbness, tingling, and weakness in your right arm started? Was it around the same time as the gait and limb ataxia started, or did it start before?

speaker: Patient
text: "I think the numbness, tingling, and weakness in my right arm started a little bit before the gait and limb ataxia. I remember noticing that my arm was feeling a bit numb and weak a few weeks before I started having trouble walking. At first, I just thought it was because I was sitting at my desk all day, but then it started to get worse and I knew something was off. And then, a few days later, I started having trouble walking and my arm was even weaker. It's like everything just kind of came together at once."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the numbness, tingling, and weakness in your right arm? Is it constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "It's kind of constant, but it can get worse at times. Like, if I'm trying to do something that requires me to use my arm, like lifting something or reaching for something, it can feel really weak and numb. But if I'm just sitting around doing nothing, it's not as bad. It's like my arm is just tired or something. But it's always there, you know? It's not like it comes and goes."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've asked all 20 questions, so now it's time for me to make a diagnosis. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I'm going to request some test results to confirm my suspicions. REQUEST TEST: Complete Blood Count (CBC), Electrolyte Panel, and Tumor Markers. Please let me know if these tests are available, and I'll proceed with the diagnosis.

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS.
